channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: BAA chief urges simpler security
item.description: Airport security checks should be made into a "single, coherent process" according to the chief executive of BAA.

item.title: Ship fire crew take to lifeboats
item.description: About 80 people on board a fishing ship which is on fire 230 miles south-west of the Isles of Scilly take to lifeboats.

item.title: Gorbachev in Nato Afghan warning
item.description: Former Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev, who withdrew his country's troops from Afghanistan, warns Nato that victory there is not possible.

item.title: Battle to reach tsunami survivors
item.description: Rescuers struggle to reach hundreds of people believed missing after a tsunami hit a group of remote Indonesian islands, killing at least 154.

item.title: No 10 denies climbdown on benefit
item.description: Downing Street denies the government is ready to amend its plans to cap the level at which housing benefit can be paid.

item.title: US execution drug 'came from UK'
item.description: The US state of Arizona says the drug it used to execute Jeffrey Landrigan was supplied by a British firm, raising concern in the UK, where there is no death penalty.

item.title: Virgin speeds up UK cable network
item.description: Virgin is turning up the dial on its cable network, offering users some of the fastest speeds in the UK.

item.title: All firms 'must offer pensions'
item.description: Every UK business should be made to offer a company pension scheme from 2012, according to a government review.

item.title: Hobbit to be made in New Zealand
item.description: Two movies based on The Hobbit will be shot in New Zealand as planned following talks with film executives, the country's prime minister confirms.

item.title: More species slide to extinction
item.description: One fifth of animal and plant species are threatened by extinction, a global study warns, but conservation efforts have pulled some back from the brink.

item.title: French pension fight goes to vote
item.description: France's parliament is set for its final vote on raising the pension age by two years after weeks of industrial action.

item.title: Boy in court over girl's murder
item.description: A 15-year-old boy is to appear in court charged with the murder of a schoolgirl whose body was found in woodland.

item.title: MSPs asked to pass emergency bill
item.description: MSPs will be asked to pass emergency laws after a major ruling says police in Scotland can no longer question suspects without access to a lawyer.

item.title: Councils uncover £135m of fraud
item.description: Almost 120,000 frauds costing £135m were uncovered by English councils last year, the Audit Commission says.

item.title: Talks over Bonfire Night strike
item.description: Talks aimed at averting a strike by London firefighters on Bonfire Night get under way in Southwark.

item.title: Inmates 'slopping out' at prison
item.description: The prisons watchdog has criticised a jail where inmates have been throwing human waste out of windows because of a lack of night-time toilets.

item.title: £600m cancer drug fund announced
item.description: Patients in England will benefit from a £600m fund to improve access to cancer drugs over the next three years, the government confirms.

item.title: Revealed - the most popular childrens names...
item.description: Oliver has become the most popular boys' name in England and Wales, ending Jack's 14-year reign, with Olivia the top girls' name, statistics reveal.

item.title: ...and the top toys on sale this Christmas
item.description: Toys linked to films and television programmes dominate a list of top toys for Christmas produced by an industry body.

item.title: Hernandez 'justifies cup praise'
item.description: Sir Alex Ferguson says Javier Hernandez, who scored a Carling Cup winner as Manchester United beat Wolves 3-2, is "justifying the praise" he is receiving for his form.

item.title: Birmingham 1-1 Brentford
item.description: Brentford bow out of the Carling Cup after Premier League Birmingham beat the brave League One side on penalties.

item.title: England lose injured star Shenton
item.description: England centre Michael Shenton is ruled out of the remainder of the Four Nations after sustaining ankle ligament damage last Saturday in Wellington.

item.title: Tweddle shrugs off age concerns
item.description: Three-time world gymnastics champion Beth Tweddle brushes aside concerns that she may be too old to win gold at the London 2012 Olympics.

item.title: McGhee praises Hartley and Bairns
item.description: Aberdeen manager Mark McGhee praises Paul Hartley's penalty kicking skill and admits his side were lucky to avoid extra-time in their win over Falkirk.

item.title: 11 arrests after boy's stab death
item.description: Eleven males are arrested after a 17-year-old boy is stabbed to death in north-west London.

item.title: Briton swept to her death in US
item.description: A 63-year-old British woman dies after being swept out to sea while on holiday in California.

item.title: Eight councils to share services
item.description: Eight local authorities in Scotland are planning to share key services in a bid to save up to £70m over five years.

item.title: Phone apps 'could boost' economy
item.description: The "lucrative" market in smartphone applications could be a huge boost to Dundee's digital economy, industry experts say.

item.title: UVF 'riots involvement worrying'
item.description: The UVF were involved in a second night of rioting in which children as young as nine were present, a senior police officer says.

item.title: Officer suspended over suicide
item.description: A police officer in NI has been suspended and a number of others are to face disciplinary action over the death in custody of a dissident republican.

item.title: Rail disabled access criticised
item.description: More than half of Wales' railway stations are not fully accessible to disabled people, according to a report.

item.title: Two hurt in estate house fires
item.description: Two people are rescued by firefighters in two separate houses fires within an hour of each other on a Wrexham housing estate.

item.title: Nigeria intercepts arms shipment
item.description: A large shipment of weapons is seized by Nigeria's secret police at a port in the city of Lagos.

item.title: Zimbabwe FA fires chief executive
item.description: The chief executive of the Zimbabwe Football Association Henrietta Rushwaya is fired after being caught up in an alleged match-fixing scandal.

item.title: Indonesian volcano toll hits 25
item.description: The death toll following the eruption of Indonesia's volatile Mt Merapi volcano rises to 25, amid fears of major fresh activity.

item.title: UN warns on Vietnam birth ratio
item.description: Sex ratios at birth are becoming increasingly imbalanced in Vietnam, with far more boys being born than girls, the UN Population Fund says.

item.title: EU 'signs off' hedge fund rules
item.description: The European Union agrees on the final form of a set of rules to provide tighter regulation of hedge funds and private equity firms.

item.title: Pope urges migrants to integrate
item.description: Pope Benedict calls on immigrants to respect the laws of host countries, in remarks likely to add to the European debate on integration.

item.title: Mexico head stresses US drug role
item.description: Mexico's President Felipe Calderon tells the BBC that the US should do more to help tackle the illegal drugs trade that has seen 28,000 deaths in his country.

item.title: Fatal bug outbreak worries Brazil
item.description: An outbreak of a drug-resistant strain of bacteria worries doctors in Brazil after a rising number of infections leads to 18 deaths in the capital, Brasilia.

item.title: Tariq Aziz is sentenced to death
item.description: Tariq Aziz, for many years the international face of Iraq under Saddam Hussein, is sentenced to death by the Iraqi Supreme Court.

item.title: Iran fuels first nuclear reactor
item.description: Iran begins fuelling its first nuclear power station at Bushehr, despite Western unease over its nuclear ambitions.

item.title: Unknown cast as Life of Pi lead
item.description: Oscar-winning director Ang Lee casts an unknown actor from India to star in his latest movie, an adaption of the novel Life of Pi.

item.title: Plea over arrested Indian rebel
item.description: The family of a separatist leader from India's Manipur state, who was arrested earlier this month, urges the government to disclose his whereabouts.

item.title: Mid-term spending nears $2bn mark
item.description: US House and Senate candidate spending nears the $2bn (£1.2bn) mark for the first time, with elections just one week away, a watchdog group says.

item.title: Canadian revelled in US killing
item.description: Omar Khadr consoled himself during his detention with memories of killing a US soldier in Afghanistan in 2002, a military tribunal hears.

item.title: EMI case banker 'can't remember'
item.description: A Citigroup banker says he cannot remember key phone calls with Terra Firma boss Guy Hands, in the EMI court case.

item.title: BAA sees sharply reduced losses
item.description: UK airports operator BAA reports a significant reduction in losses and strong growth in passenger numbers.

item.title: Deutsche sees loss of 1.2bn euros
item.description: Deutsche Bank reports a loss for the third quarter, brought about by costs related to its planned purchase of Deutsche Postbank.

item.title: UK recovery steady, says Osborne
item.description: George Osborne says better-than-expected economic figures show the recovery is "steady", but Labour warns that spending cuts will damage performance.

item.title: Clegg fury over 'cleansing' claim
item.description: Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg denies Labour claims that large cities will be "cleansed" of poor people following cuts to housing benefits.

item.title: Transport schemes get green light
item.description: Transport Secretary Philip Hammond gives the green light for 16 road, bus and rail improvement schemes which he says are a "key driver" of future growth.

item.title: Tall men risk testicular cancer
item.description: Taller men appear to be at increased risk of testicular cancer, US experts discover, after surveying data on 10,000 men.

item.title: Call for more club paramedics
item.description: A&E doctors say nightclubs have a responsibility to employ more qualified paramedics to ease the strain on hospitals.

item.title: 'Contraceptive gel' shows promise
item.description: A birth control gel that is applied directly to the skin could offer women an alternative to the Pill, say experts presenting latest trial data.

item.title: UK young people feel 'isolated'
item.description: More than a third of young people in the UK aged 16 to 24 do not feel part of their local community, research by the Prince's Trust suggests.

item.title: Baby P 'failed by all agencies'
item.description: Reports show Baby Peter's "horrifying death" was down to the incompetence of almost every member of staff who came into contact with him.

item.title: Humanities to lose teaching grant
item.description: David Willetts suggests university teaching grants for arts, humanities and social sciences will be phased out.

item.title: Yahoo Mail gets major revamp
item.description: Yahoo Mail is getting its biggest redesign since 2005 to make it a message hub for its 279 million users.

item.title: UN urges Wikileaks torture probe
item.description: The US and Iraq should investigate claims by the Wikileaks website that Iraqi forces tortured citizens during the US-led war, the UN says.

item.title: Users lax about mobile security
item.description: Seven out of 10 people store sensitive information on their phones with no security, new research has found.

item.title: US lab clears Higgs hunt hurdle
item.description: An expert panel has recommended extending the lifetime of a US "particle smasher" by three years.

item.title: Assassin bug mimics spider prey
item.description: Scientists have described how a species of insect, known as assassin bugs, lures spiders by mimicking prey caught in webs.

item.title: European sat-nav contract awarded
item.description: The German-led consortium SpaceOpal will run the satellite system that will form Europe's answer to GPS, known as Galileo.

item.title: Walliams wife wins Playboy case
item.description: Model Lara Stone, the wife of comic actor David Walliams, wins damages from French Playboy after it published unauthorised photos of her.

item.title: Take That and Robbie confirm tour
item.description: Robbie Williams is to tour with Take That for the first time in 16 years when the reunited group go on a stadium tour next summer.

item.title: Sheen released from NY hospital
item.description: Two and a Half Men actor Charlie Sheen is released from hospital following an "episode" in a New York hotel.

item.title: Could you stay silent for eight days?
item.description: With constant communication and 24hr television, it is hard to find even eight minutes of silence. But what would happen if you were asked to stay quiet for over a week?

item.title: What's behind the all-powerful 'i'?
item.description: The UK has a new national newspaper, which its creators have called i. So what is it about the letter that has made it so popular?

item.title: Meet the Simpsons from Springfield
item.description: The third in a series looking at the US elections through the prism of popular television shows turns to a family with a very famous surname.

item.title: Nick Clegg rejects social 'cleansing' claims
item.description: Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg has fiercely criticised a Labour frontbencher for suggesting that the coalition was "sociologically cleansing" poorer citizens out of London.

item.title: Government faces call to scrap Lords reform
item.description: Ministers have been urged to scrap plans to make the House of Lords a directly elected chamber.

item.title: Live: Health Committee
item.description: The Health Committee is scrutinising the Palliative Care Bill.

item.title: Test tube miracles
item.description: 25 years of IVF treatment at one of the UK's first dedicated centres

item.title: James Bond's Aston Martin for sale
item.description: James Bond's gadget-packed 1964 Aston Martin DB5 - the one from Goldfinger and Thunderball - is expected to fetch millions of pounds at a lavish car auction in London on Wednesday.

item.title: How US state deals with drink crime
item.description: A stringent project designed to curb alcohol-related crime in the US state of South Dakota is to be used as a model for a project in the UK.

item.title: Indonesia struggles with twin disasters
item.description: Rescue teams are trying to reach remote islands to save survivors from a tsunami while in Java authorities are moving people away from the volcano Mount Merapi

item.title: Inside a Haiti camp threatened by cholera
item.description: The Haitian government tries to prevent a cholera outbreak in the north-west of the country moving to the capital Port-au-Prince.

item.title: Night protest over Italian waste dump
item.description: Thousands of people took part in an all-night march between Pompeii and Terzigno on Tuesday in protest at the government's plans to open a second waste dump in Terzigno.

item.title: Emperor stag shot on Exmoor
item.description: A 9ft-tall Exmoor stag called the Emperor, thought to be the biggest wild land animal in the UK, has been shot.

item.title: US mid-term election sprint takes off
item.description: After months of campaigning and more than $2bn (£1.3bn) spent, there is just one week to go until the mid-term elections. Katty Kay looks at the seven-day sprint.

item.title: Dutch orchestra's musical protest
item.description: Members of the Dutch orchestra demonstrated against funding cuts by staging a concert at The Hague central railway station.

item.title: World's weirdest migration?
item.description: A megaphone, a microlight, and some confused birds

item.title: Voice of an angel
item.description: Charlotte Church on fame, family and music

item.title: Please don't marry me
item.description: Why would a straight couple want a civil partnership?

item.title: Feline female
item.description: Why do some women devote their lives to cats?

item.title: Dream to die
item.description: Pakistani boy who wanted to be a suicide bomber

item.title: Fuelling the economy
item.description: Life on the £200m gas platform that can be used again and again

item.title: Speed freaks
item.description: Could you stomach the world's fastest rollercoaster?
